revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Mycena luteopallens2.jpg | image_width= 234px | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Mycenaceae]] | genus = ''[[Mycena]]'' | species = '''''M. crocea''''' | binomial = ''Mycena crocea'' | binomial_authority = Maas Geesteranus (1991) | synonyms = ''Marasmius nucicola'' McDougall (1925)
''Mycena luteopallens'' sensu A. H. Smith (1947) non type }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Mycena crocea'' | hymeniumType = gills | capShape = conical | capShape2 = convex | whichGills = adnate | stipeCharacter = bare | sporePrintColor = white | ecologicalType = saprotrophic | howEdible = unknown }} {{stack end}} '''''Mycena crocea''''', commonly known as the '''walnut mycena''', is a species of [[mushroom]] in the [[Mycenaceae]] family. The small, inconsequentially edible mushroom has a bright yellow, conical to broadly convex [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] up to {{convert|15|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is tough and thin, up to {{convert|20|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} tall, bright yellow at the top becoming progressively orange towards the base. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are adnate, subdistant, and yellowish, becoming lighter in age; and the [[spore print]] is white. This mushroom is [[saprobic]] and found exclusively on hickory nuts and walnuts in eastern North America. The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''crocea'' refers to the orange color. The mushroom is [[common name|commonly]] known as the "walnut mycena" and was previously and commonly misidentified as ''Mycena luteopallens''. ==Description== The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is vivid yellow, conical to broadly convex [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] and up to {{convert|15|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter. When young the cap tends to be conical or bell-shaped becoming plane or flat at maturity. The margin is striated. The surface is moist, glabrous, and somewhat [[hygrophanous]]. The flesh is thin, pallid, and yellowish. Odor and taste are not distinctive. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] have an adnate attachment and are a pale yellowish color. They are subdistantly spaced. The sturdy [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|10|to|20|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|1|to|1.5|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} thick. The stipe is central, equal (i.e., roughly equal in thickness at the top and bottom), and dark orange to yellowish ===Microscopic characteristics=== The [[spore]]s are 7–9 x 4–5 µm, smooth, and elliptical, and weakly amyloid to inamyloid. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia are present ===Similar species=== ''[[Mycena strobilinoides]]'' is similar to ''M. crocea'', but is found in needle beds under conifers. ''[[Atheniella adonis]]'' has a fragile stem and a more reddish-pink coloration.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} ==Habitat and distribution== ''Mycena crocea'' are found exclusively on hickory nuts and walnuts in eastern North America. It was first described as ''Marasmius nucicola'' in 1925 but that name could not be used in ''Mycena''.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite journal |author=Maas Geesteranus RA. |title=Studies in Mycenas. Additions and corrections, Part 1|journal=Proc. Kon. Ned. Akad. v. Wetensch. |volume=94 |pages=377–403 |year=1991 }} }} {{Taxonbar|from=Q5244920}} [[Category:Mycena|crocea]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1991]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Inedible fungi]]
